content.question: The elements <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="S e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Se</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> have the same electronegativity value, 2.55. Which of the following claims about the compound that forms from <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="S e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Se</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is most likely to be true?

choices.label: The carbon-to-selenium bond is nonpolar covalent.
The compound has the empirical formula <math alttext="C S e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CSe</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
A molecule of the compound will have a partial negative charge on the carbon atom.

content.answer: The carbon-to-selenium bond is nonpolar covalent.
